comment: The Little Corner With Explosive Food The only reason why we heard of this place was because we heard it replaced Peramakan at TANGS Marketplace. After getting a taste of how good they were (and seeing how people constantly came by to buy their kuehs and nonya rice dumplings), we knew we had to try the food from their main restaurant at Telok Blangah. Firstly, I'd like to apologize for the lack of photos, especially of the food. We decided at the spur of the moment to rush down and take away a few dishes for a family lunch. Because of our hunger and over enthusiasm to try the food, we completely forgot about photos. Promise to upload a few the next time I'm there. Now.... back to food. I've noticed that there's been a lot of disagreements and "arguments" online lately about how "authentic" a Peranakan Restaurant is. Because of the many influences and different background of each family, and lack of belief in writing down recipes, there isn't really a genuine, authentic recipe for Nonya food. Sure, the basic ingredients are the same, but the way it's cooked varies from family to family. To me, good Nonya food needs to be the following: 1. it has to be fragrant. A lot of Peranakan dishes depend on a solid rempah (spice blend / paste) and this should stand out in all dishes2. It has to be delicious 3. It has to feel like it's prepare with love 4. It has to warm the soul Nonya Chap Chye ($14.90)After the trying so many variations of Chao Chye, from Singapore to Malacca, from home cooked to higher end restaurants, I can proudly say that this Chap Chye is up there with the best. The bean curd skin taste is not overpowering and compliments the natural sweetness of the cabbage very well and the vegetables are soft yet not overcooked to mush. Really delicious. Assam Fish Curry ($11.90)Wow..... just wow! What's great about this Assam is that it's not overly spicy but it packs a punch. Be warned, the first bite might feel a bit overpowering, with an explosion of sourness, tanginess and slight sweetness, with each bite feeling like mini fireworks going off in the mouth but as you keep eating, the flavours mellow down, leaving a nice, almost soothing after taste in the mouth. Beef Rendang ($14.90)Another dish cooked with a lot of care and love. The sauce was slightly on the spicy side (very spicy to the wife who's a non-chilli eater) but it certainly packed a punch. The sauce was fragrant and rich without being overpowering. Once the initial spiciness cleared, the rempah came through, showcasing the fragrant spices used, mixed in with the beefiness from stewing the Rendang. Most importantly was the beef. It was cooked to perfection. Wonderfully tender, the meat fell off the fork while we were trying to pick it up. Another very well executed dish. Ayam Buah Keluak ($16.90 + $5.00 for 2 seeds of Buah Keluak)My holy grail of Nonya Cuisine. My biggest weakness and most absolute must have for any Peranakan Restaurant and the ones here have the best Buah Keluak I've had..... ever! Firstly, it's interesting how they used a mixture of Pork Ribs and Chicken instead of just solely chicken. The proteins were cooked perfectly, juicy and tender. Interestingly, because we took away, they actually separated the protein from the Buah Keluak. This gave us the chance to taste the rempah separately and again, it was very good. Fragrant and very tasty, the sauce acted as an enhancement to the protein and not over power it but the spotlight definitely goes to the Buah Keluak. Removed from the shells, blended smooth and re-stuffed, the Buah Keluaks tasted almost like a paté, packed with that rich, delicious black gold. Should you want the more familiar style of Ayam Buah Keluak, feel free to mix it both together. We did that eventually and the thick, black yumminess of the Buah Keluak helped elevate the rempah to another level. 2 thumbs and 2 toes up for me! Nonya Rice Dumpling ($3.90 at TANGS Marketplace) Ma little pricy in terms of rice dumplings (maybe because it's TANGS). I have to admit, my favourite is still Kim Choo but that could just be me being bias. However, it still was a pretty good Nonya Zhang. The rice is not as fragrant and tasty as other I've tried but it did compliment the filling well, ensuring that the sweetness, saltiness and juiciness of the filling took centre stage. Pineapple Tarts ($19.00 - we think)First bite? We were disappointed. The pastry wasn't as buttery or flavourful as some of the other tarts we've tried but once we reached the filling we understood why. The filling was very very good. The Palm sugar shone through and there was a richness and depth to it that a lot of other pineapple filling didn't have. It felt like it was prepared the traditional way, stewing hours in a copper pot and allowing the sweetness, tartness and spices to blend into a yummy, gooey mix. On a whole, we loved the vibe of the restaurant and the food was way above expectations!

It's hard not to get a little sentimental stepping into a place like Makko.  The feel of the place evokes memories of happier, simpler times for me, of days past when a special treat meant walking hand in hand into a place just like Makko with a doting aunt or grandmother to have ondeh-ondeh or kueh kosui for tea.  So for me, Makko or places like it will always have an unfair advantage of my nostalgia.  Thanks for being around, Makko!What always does it for me...Dry Mee Siam.  This is the house special and if you get there late, they're usually out.  So you might want to call ahead before hoofing it all the way out to Telok Blangah Rise.  Words are not really up to the task of adequately conveying how full of flavor this apparently simple dish is.  it It may just look like bee hoon or fine rice noodles but every mouthful is redolent with fresh lime, Kaffir lime leaf, lemongrass, fresh chili, sambal and maybe some candlenut...beyond that my palate is so happily saturated and it's more about how much I'm enjoying every bite and less about what's in it.  Definitely the star here at Makko!What did it for me this time round...Tauhu Goreng.  Deep-fried semi-firm tofu under shredded cucumber, bean sprouts and a mountainous helping of spicy peanut sauce (satay sauce).  The veggies are hard to get wrong and Makko doesn't.  The sauce is the kicker with an unctuous nuttiness and a piquant twist, this part of the palate actually reminds me of a nice brown or amber ale. Always one of my favorite local dishes for its craftiness, where an almost overwhelmingly bold sauce is paired with tofu, cucumber and sprouts, inherently bland tasting elements.  Pure genius!Nonya Ngoh Hiang.  Makko's version of this local Teochew classic is lightly crunchy on the outside, filled with juicy morsels of minced meat and has a nice aromatic spiciness to balance all the gravidity of this deep-fried meat spring roll wrapped in tofu skin.Chicken Wings.  These are deep-fried as well in a batter that confers on each morsel a thick armored plating of screamingly hot, crunchy, spicy, gingery, greasy, juicy goodness.  I cannot thick of a better arch-nemesis to Korean-style fried chicken which has skin that is almost painted on and air light. I recommend having these fresh with a cold beer where you can slowly pick apart every bit of the wing and enjoy every spicy, crunchy bit of armor plating.  The subtle yellow ginger flavor suffusing every bite is pure genius.

rest_name: Kee Hiong Klang Herbal Bak Kut Teh
comment: The outlet was a stall in the Alexandra Hospital cafeteria, which was located away from the main block. When we reached the place at 6.30pm, all the other stalls were closed except this. The 2 staffs were cheerful although there was a slight issue in processing our order. Help yourself to the condiements such as sliced red chilli, light soya sauce and dark soya sauce.Tua Kut (Big Bone) (Soup) 干肉骨茶 (S$9.50)It was a huge piece of bone packed with fatty meat around in a claypot which looked too small to accommodated it. The broth was herbal which was typical of malaysian style. The meat which looked scary with its thick layer of fat was melt in the mouth.Dry Bak Kut Teh 干肉骨茶 (S$8.80)Served in a claypot with slices of chilli in it. It was accompanied with a bowl of the bak kut teh broth by the side. Although the meat looked quite fatty, but it was not jelat and tasted quite flavourful. If they could serve pig's intestines in this version, it would be even better.Preserved Vegetables 梅菜 (S$2.2.0)The mei cai (preserved mustard) was soft and flavourful, without too salty. Just nice to go with the garlic rice (S$0.70).

address: 43 Siloso Beach Walk #05-01 Southern Islands 099010 Singapore
comment: If you are in this part of Sentosa, you have already accepted the tourists and the families, but rise above (you have to grab the elevator which is a little tricky to find) and enjoy a beautiful view of the sunset in Singapore (trumped only by the casino pool deck of course). great drinks, good happy hour prices, open air and great for you and a few friends.

Why did I eat at IKEA?! Because this one apparently has really good Fried Chicken Wings and it's right next to the Park Hotel Alexandra, where I was staying. So it satisfied both my curiosity and desire not to walk too far in the hot humid air.Never Eaten at IKEA?It's cafeteria style where you put what you want on a tray or ask for it from behind the counter before checking out.  I always forget they have fountain sparkling juices after the checkout, but they need to be purchased before checkout.Fried Chicken WingsThey give you the whole wing as one wing- drum to tip- are sold in twos, and they are hot, crispy, deep fried skin with seasoning but not breaded.  Perfect.Veggie BallsAppeared to be a mixture of broccoli, chickpea, carrots, and maybe some soy to hold it all together.  Flavor-wise, these got a little boring after 4 of them, but just a dip of that Thai Curry spiced it up real quick again.  Thai Coconut CurryStarted off just tasting well seasoned but the spices built quickly and I found myself backing off the Curry after a few dips.Veggie Cous CousDry, light, and fluffy but flavorful... (if they weren't dry they probably wouldn't be Cous cous.)

If you're in Singapore definitely go try IKEA!!!! I know you might think "why IKEA????" but the food in IKEA Singapore is so unique and delicious!!!!!!!! They have the classic meatballs but I highly recommend getting the pork knuckle or the chicken wings!!!!! The chicken wings are fried perfectly and have an amazing flavour!!!! On the other hand the boneless pork knuckle is massive and extremely juicy!!!! Honestly if you're able to finish the pork knuckle you're a legend (it's that big!!!!!!)!!!! Also definitely try their ice cream!!!!!!!! The ice cream is soy flavour which is really unique and it is very refreshing especially in the hot weather in Singapore!!!!! If you want to try something different or just want a challenge definitely go to IKEA!!!!! You might want to get there early though because it gets rammed pretty early!!!!

After looking at furniture for about an hour, decided to have lunch at the Ikea restaurant. It was near to 2pm, and there was still a queue extending back pass the drinks & coffee island. But luckily the queue moved fast.We ordered the 2 must do - the meatballs and the fried chicken wings. Additionally, we ordered the fish& chips and the confit of duck. We also had the Swedish fruit flavour drinks.The meatballs goes well with the sauce and cranberry sauce. There were lots of meatballs with a good amount of boiled potatoes.The duck was also good and it came with boiled potatoes and steamed vegetables (carrots). The duck meat was tender and goes well with the given sauce. it was tasty. You get an entire duck drumstick. The chicken wings was crispy and moist. It was marinated very well and was tasty. It was very good.The worst dish was fish and chips. It mediocre and basic. You get a breaded fish with chips. It came with the normal tartar sauce. The fried part of the fish was crispy but overall it was rather cold probably it was dished on the plate out of the heating lamp waiting for some poor customer to take it.The Swedish fruity drink was refreshing as it was very fizzy. Unfortunately Ikea does not provide ice at this location. So the cold drink quickly became room temperature while you dig in to the main course. It was very refreshing and cool when you first got it from the dispenser. It seems that all drinks are refillable
Cheap eats in a nice setting minus the crowdWhat more can we ask for when the feet is tired and the kids are grouchy. Food and drinks.If the food is good and better when is cheap. Heavenly.

Hard to fault this place. Cheap food. Quick service. Amongst the best chicken wings in Singapore and you'll be able to get some furniture shopping in after you're done eating as well. Most of the dishes worth having are "Western" but the curry is among the best that you can get in a fast food-ish place. Free flow soft drinks for a dollar as well as free baby food. Can't deny that my wife and I are just in love with IKEA.

My family loves IKEA Alexandra and it's restaurant. We just do. Many complain but we're still fans. They have a new dish on the menu and it's Pork Ribs with Fries. Well, the ribs are a generous slab of about 5 ribs. Tasty wise is ok but a tad too dry. It's without sauce so the overall pretty dry. The other dishes are well covered so I won't add on. I'll be back definitely!

Half the staff act like you're annoying them when you ask for assistance, and their first instinct is "Cannot." The delivery service was appalling. They set a window of 1-4pm, called at 1pm to say they'd be here in 30 minutes, and then just rang at 4:15 to say they'd be here at 5. Pathetic. I may try Castlery next time.
My friends and I love going to IKEA, not for any furniture, just for dinner. We like the meatballs and the smoky salmon:)

A great place for a casual meal of comfort foods and snacks! The foods here are affordable but you do everything yourself, from queueing up, to getting your food, all the way to clearing your own table, but for the affordable prices they offer, you can't really complain. It is also children friendly, with a special corner allocated for families with children, complete with baby chairs and toys to entertain them while the parents have their meal.They do great swedish meatballs and their chicken wings are especially yummy too! They often have set meals that are worth getting and drinks are refillable! Their desserts are also pretty cheap and interesting. Try their Daim tart! Sweet and nutty goodness in every bite!

This may seem strange but I literally come all the way down the IKEA exit bistro just to get cheapo but tasty hot dogs.I find the prices here absolutely ridiculous for a filling meal. At $1 a hotdog I never stop at just one, or two. A hotdog and a drink sets you back a mere $1.50, so you're set for a complete lunchtime bite. You even get the thrill of squeezing the sauces out of the udder-like contraptions, which is always  fun sight for kids. You could even get a soft serve ice cream cone here for 50 cents, and you know they'd do it better than Macdonalds does it. Despite their limited menu I really adore how quick and efficient everything is, and the fact that I can have a very filling and satisfying meal for under $5. What I usually do is grab meself a hotdog and walk around their little food collection next to the counter so see what Swedish food tempts me. An entertaining lunch in a very odd way!

I've always been a greater fan of Ikea's food rather than its furniture, and its bistro is the greatest reason why. The bistro strangely epitomizes the proud qualities of ikea- fuss free, brainless assembly and shopper friendly. Things are kept simple here: you first place and pay for your order at a counter, then move along in a somewhat production-line fashion to wait for your food to be prepared upon presentation of your receipt. The magical part is there is hardly ever a queue so you are literally seconds from a hot steamy sausage bun.The hotdog is of course the best seller. Its so ridiculously simple, cheap and good it makes you realize those people paying for $5 hotdogs outside zouk must be seriously drunk. It consists of a boiled medium length chicken sausage (ain't no bratwurst) sandwiched between a fresh bun, and you move on to dress it with the sauces of your choice, my favorite being an excessive amount of mustard and chilli sauce. Since last year they have also introduced a chilled chocolate doughnut that is not mind blowing but still sweet enough to fix that sugar craving.The only thing I never liked from the bistro is the signature lingonberry drink. It tastes so weird and doesn't appeal to my Asian palette at all. I have never met anyone who likes it, I wonder why they insist on keeping it on the menu. Also, I don't think the drink goes well with the food on the menu because I truly think a hotdog is best enjoyed with good ol coca cola!

Enough said , when you think of Ikea, immediately the swedish meat ball will be the top of mind. Everything here is self service, ranging from collection of eating utensil, food to clearing of tray.The meat ball comes with their own sauce as well as their lingo berry jam which taste lovely when you eat them as a whole. if you are a fan of the jam, you may request for more sauce. Another food not to be miss is the fried chicken wings, it is well marinated , sinful as it may seem, one will succumb to indulgence. Also, for sweet tooth, the dessert section offers unique pastries and cakes, one of them is the princess cake that is covered with a sweet green kaya layer.During rush hours, tables might be hard to get and queues might be long but the food is definitely worth the hassle.

IKEA has been our go-to source for Swedish meatballs for as long as I can remember. They have expanded their offerings to include a selection of local and other Swedish options, with a daily evolving menu so one is almost always guaranteed to be able try something new.Food : The meatballs are a mixture of beef and pork meatballs. Accompanied by a tasty gravy and lingonberry jam with a side of steamed potatoes, it is one of the signature dishes of the restaurant. The fish and chips are quite good, as is the poached salmon. The chicken wings are pretty awesome and the baked chicken leg comes in a generous portion. The soup changes daily but are usually quite decent. There are also daily breakfast options from 9am with a selection of pancakes, hash browns, scrambled eggs and waffles.Ambience : Busy and casualService : Self service but the IKEA staff serving at the counter are pleasant

We used to go there once a week, after school. Now I go a lot less, but hey, where else can you go to get a mix of chicken wings and nostalgia? Other than the crowdpleasers (meatballs, chicken wings), watch out for their specials, though not everything is worth eating (to wit, their Swedish crayfish special was meagre). And save room for dessert! Daim pie (yes Daim as in the candy) is a favorite, as is princess cake when it's available. If you like the food, do check out the food shop downstairs, because a lot of that stuff is available frozen to bring home.

The most expensive pancakes of my life - was it worth it?  Depends on how much you like pancakes! :-) But seriously, this isn't like any other pancake you'll have and while you need to get there early to make sure you have a place (they consistently sell out of the special pancakes and everyone in your party needs to buy at least one item, though they don't all have to buy pancakes).

If you want to try the infamous Japanese fluffy pancakes head to Gram in Vivo City HarbourFront Singapore!!!!! The pancakes are extremely light, fluffy and really jiggly!!!!! They go great with syrup, butter and a lot of cream!!!!!!! They are extremely flavourful as well!!!! Just make sure that you arrive and lineup outside the store at 11:00, 3:00 or 6:00!!!!!! Every person has to order something as well so try out the mango and green tea frappes if you don't want too many pancakes!!!! The frappés are very refreshing and extremely flavourful!!!! Go try this place out!!!!

A quiet location under a block of HDB flats in bukit merah. The staff are friendly. Free wifi is nice. The food is pretty good and reasonably pricedSalmon eggs Benedict $12.90The eggs weren't very runny but the avocado serving was generous and the toast was pretty good! Loved the salmonMeaty Mac and cheese $14.80A Tad dry imho but still a good bowl of Mac n cheeseWill be back!!!!

They have a well seasoned wok! You can taste the smoky goodness in each bite of the hor fun.  They make the hor fun first and plate it. Then they fire up some beef and gravy remove. Then wok up some eggs and return the beef gravy back to the wok, stir and plate. You just don't see the multiple steps at other places. Yum! The beef hor fun is item #1 on the menu and $4.

Timbre+ as a concept is pretty cool.  An artful amalgamation of East and West.  Take a bunch of western-style food trucks serving pizza, American, and French and park them in an airy hawkers center amidst more familiar offerings like a sarabat stall, fishball mee and an aunty hawking fresh fruit juice and cut fruit and you might just have a recipe for something pretty special.Timbre + has a lot going for it, and I do hope that the "hawkers" and the management team that had the cajones to put it all together live long and prosper!  I really do!    I'm truly happy that someone has the steel tripe to gamble against conventional wisdom and plant a venture like Timbre+ in the middle of what used to be Ayer Rajah Industrial Park.  The result is, of course, something quite different.  The feel of the place is not quite urban hip because this isn't Orchard or even the river district, but take a closer look and you find an edgy cool and slightly grungy concept of a location.  Sit down with a craft beer from the abundantly provisioned Bottle Shop and a consider your surroundings with a more studied eye and you begin to understand that the haphazardness is a facade. Timbre + is a considered, thoughtfully laid out, and well put together concept.  Take for example the height of the ceiling and the prodigious number of Big Ass Fans that are lazily whirring overhead to keep the entire interior of this, essentially al fresco space airy, breezy and cool without being uninvitingly cave-like. To me, this demonstrates one very important thing.  The powers that be of this place had the good sense to get the basics right without being totally overwhelmed by their enthusiasm for a fancy concept.   This happens all too often in Singapore where you have a totally awesome concept that falls flat on execution because nobody bothered to sit down and sweat the details, things like the ambient temperature, how tables are going to be bussed, and how a capacity crowd could be seated comfortably.  Kudos, Timbre + bosses!!Put simply, I WANT Timbre + to succeed because success suggests the following:1.  That more of Singapore will be explored for dining and entertainment.  You don't have to be downtown to be a success.2.  Singaporeans are a discerning enough crowd to know a good thing when they see it and are not deterred by unconventional locations.3.  Unconventional locations = lower rents = more investment in quality.  If we could only get enough Singaporeans behind this concept, we could all enjoy better quality, more consistency and fewer chain concepts.4.  The Singapore palate would have the space and the opportunity to mature, become more sophisticated and more discerning.  Ultimately, this is a good thing.  More variety, fresher preparations, higher quality ingredients and less reliance on bulk and mass-production is a good and healthy thing.
Lively place with quite a few food options, including burgers asian and indian food. Live music in the evenings. Phenomenal place, highly recommend it.

I came here on a Friday night and as a result got to enjoy the live music with our dinner, which was really fun! The cover band was pretty good, and combined with the aesthetic of the building as a whole (the walls were made of painted shipping containers which I thought was really cool) it was a fun, relaxed vibe that's very different from a lot of other places in Singapore. It was kind of similar to a Hawker center in that there were different food stalls to choose from, but the options were more diverse. We sampled quite a few dishes, with my favorite being the most delicious calamari I've ever had - it was so buttery and fried to perfection. It's such a great place to go with a bunch of friends to grab a drink and relax, and I would love to go back if I am in the area again.

Good news/bad news. The good news is, I had the most incredible wings from a booth called Two Wings. I mean fabulous.  Perfectly cooked and seasoned. More good news. They had a beer place called the Bottle Shop with beers from all over the world. A bit pricey, but a great selection. The bad news is from a booth called Urban Smokehouse. Terrible. The ribs were cold and tasteless, the sausages were dry, and the pork belly was just meh. We were really disappointed. They had a local band playing tonight. Really good. Go for the music, wings, and beer, but stay away from Urban. Cheers all.

Yelpers have described this as an upscale hawker centre and I couldn't agree more. I had the opportunity to visit timbre+ on a weekday after work. At first I was surprised to see that many of the stalls nearer of the street were closed, many of them being local food. As you draw deeper into the warehouse like place, you'll see the stage for the live band and more food options. On a Wed night, about half of the stalls were often, most of which were non-traditional options (ie: French, Indian Kati rolls, Spanish tapas). I ordered a French Onion Soup from the French stall and a Chicken Kati Roll from the Indian stall. My friend tried the Japanese rice bowl and Salted egg fries from Kuchi.  Sadly I was underwhelmed by all 4 items we had on our shared table. There was a live band who sung Bohemian Rhapsody during our dinner. The fans created a surprisingly well ventilated and casual  atmosphere, but the food was unimpressive and not cheap. It was fun to check it out to see what the hype was about, but I don't see myself coming back very often, given how mediocre the food was.

The place used to house a hawker centre which offered the cheapest priced food in area with fresh fruit juice priced from $1 and rice with 3 sides from $2.50 onwards. I was so sad that the hawker centre was taken away. In its place, now taken over by atas hawker centre called Timbre+, with prices more than double. The place quite hot and humid. So the number one to do when one plan to eat here is to look for a table in front of the huge fans.Do take note that most stalls charge $1 for tray which would be refunded when the tray is returned. So remember do not give the tray to the cleaning uncle when he comes by.The Garcons stall offers french food. Order is taken through the self service machine. Only cash, NETS and NETS flashpay is accepted here. Remember in the number on the pagar which can found next to the machine.BANGERS AND MASH ($16.30).Spanish Chorizo (pork), German Bratwurst (Pork), Chicken Cheese Sasusge (Chicken) served with mashed potato, double mustard and petit saladThe sausages were quite huge. One of the sausages had a taste which was similar to otah.The well known Two Wings also has a stall here. Remember to show that you have a Pokeman Go account, where you will get a lucky dip which could be a discount or a free drink. Chicken Wings ($8.60/ 6 pieces)Topped with chilli crab sauce. Not as eggy as the dish found in most zhi char stalls. The version here was more tangy sweet.Food Anatomy is a stall which offered food such as Nasi Lemak, Salted Egg Prawn on Charcoal Bun in cube forms. We selected 3 items on the display shelves which cost $10.80.Cold SobaThe sauce was in a kind of gel form on top of the soba. The sauce was not bad, but a bit too little and let down by the bland and slightly uncooked soba.Pork LasagneColorful looking with black, green and pink pasta sheets. It was quite moist and tasty.Yuzu Cream with Matcha GenoiseThe yuzu cream was light and refreshing, but melt easily, which helped to keep the matcha cake below moist. Could not really taste the matcha flavour below.

No no no no! That's the first emotion which comes to mind when thinking about Timbre+. This place has so much potential but unfortunately fails to deliver.When I came here first, I had high hopes, the place has a cool vibe and looks fun. Also, they have a live band which is always a nice touch, even when the band is soso, because, let's be honest, you're here for the food, aren't you?Uhm... let's just say that once you try the food you start wishing you came for the band. I tried Food Anatomy which serves small dishes in blocks, difficult to describe but very instagramable so I am sure you can find some pics online. It was all about the looks though, we did not finish our dishes and decided to go to the Star Vista to get other food.However, since I liked the atmosphere I decided to give the place another try a few months later. Since I am a big fan of a good Kaisen Don I tried out Teppei Daidokoro. Again... fail: it does not compare to the other branches of Teppei, the fish was slightly warmish (for raw fish?) and had only salmon with the tiniest sprinkle of ikura. My friend had a po-boy from Big Bern's American Grill and mentioned that Louisiana should ban these people for insulting their signature dish!I would describe this place as a hipster hawker centre gone wrong but according the website it is a gastropark - to each their own I guess, but not for me.

New Timbre concept in Singapore, and yay I've always been a Timbre fan since 2010!TImbre has been known for "Home for Singapore Musicians" when they first started out. We decided to visit timbre+ for TGIF with zero expectation. My group of friends, 4 of us, arrived at 9pm. We noticed that the space is huge with ample of seats available to host large groups of people. It was fully packed with people at that time, music level is high with the band (Supersonic) on Friday night and a pretty warm location despite huge fans spinning on top of our heads.Within minutes, we were able to find ourselves seated in a comfortable position enjoying the music brought to us by local band. Particularly I love the female lead singer from Supersonic, whose energy level was really high with her singing and dancing on stage. Towards the end of their 2nd set of the night, the male lead singer came down the stage and engaged the audiences with friendly handshake and singing together with the audiences. I thought it was really perfect performances for the night!We split up and got ourselves some food for sharing. We ordered food from Chit Chaat Chai, Teppei Daidokoro, Kush and Two Wings. There are too many stalls to explore and try within one night, so I'm sure this entices multiple visits to this place! We had a papdi chaat from Chit Chaat Chai, a popular indian snack/street food in India - a dish mixed with yogurt, mini papadum, some mint and indian spices. A mixed platter of yakitori from Teppei Daidokoro, salted egg yolk fries, luncheon fries and skewers from Kush, and salted egg yolk wings from Two Wings. Good thing that the salted egg yolk from fries are separated in a bowl from the fries, we did not get sick over 2 dishes of salted egg yolk in one night. The food selection is really great with so many options to choose from! The only dish I dislike for the night are the skewers from Kush, should just stick to Teppei next time.Now, Timbre is known for their beer and pizza. Beer selection was a total disappointment from this space, and the purchase takes a very long time. There is no sight of Timbre pizza too. There are fridges stocked up with craft beer only, and Archipelago draft on tap. I was hoping to get a tower of beer for all my friends for sharing, but nope, no tower available. I guess there is something they could do about to the payment of beer purchase for sure. There is only 1 counter for payment. Well, but I'm pretty cool with everything, because there's so much other positive stuff over this beer counter.We spent less than $40 per pax for the entire night with good food and entertainment. It's quite worth it with a bunch of friends to chill out. Cab home is problem. We can barely find any cab on the road, so we walked over to the main street and waited a while before we can get home. It's also a great space for family too! I saw really small babies in the arms of mummies, and they are not crying babies!On the other hand, we spotted normal hawker stalls on our way out, like fish soup, fruit juice, handmade noodle stalls etc. We also notice the graffiti sprayed outside the container, all done by local talents.  It's an exciting space with a lot of local flavour, which I give it 5 stars! However, in Singapore, you probably still need some cooling space... or awesome cold beers. I'll be back for more, and I'm so glad and proud that Timbre came up with such awesome space!

This is my 1st time here. The builded up look interesting with the large shipping containers around & high ceilings. The food there are of a sort of local & speciality style. A bit different from our hawker stores.There's a alcohol store, but they serve only boutique beers in bottle (mostly S$11 & above) and Archipelago beer in draught $13.I came here to try the food & I ordered the Wagyu beef rendang with rice, sambal kang kong & onsen egg...S$14.80 + S$1 (tray charge $1, which you can get back when you return the tray)Why 4 stars.....well it gets very warm when the weather is hot even thought there's fan around including the evening time too . If not the warm air around, I would have given it 5 stars.

What a disappointment! I really wanted to love this place, but I just couldn't...We went at 3:30pm on a Wednesday (because that's when we were hungry). I got the impression many places probably closed around 3pm - over half the stalls were shut.  Visually, it makes a great impression - there's great street art on the outside, and the combo of stalls and food trucks and art is really cute on the inside. I didn't have any problems with the heat - there was plenty of wind from the million fans they have,The tray return was a highlight, unfortunately, which shouldn't be the case when you're going for food. There are signs everywhere that let you know how it works, so if you insist on wasting your money here, head to the tray return and claim your SG$1 back when you're finished.Food here ranges from "a bit pricey for a hawker centre" to "WTF?! We're not at a restaurant!" We wound up spending $26 on Indian food that was served mostly *cold*. Not just room temperature, but actually cold. (Shocking, considering how hot it is here - I'm not sure how they managed that.)  The set meals were a ridiculously large portion of rice with some small scoops of cold vegetables. The butter chicken was a small dish with about 3 pieces of chicken in it, barely room temp.  The yellow dahl was the best thing we had - it was a nice consistency and good mixture of spices. The masala chai was also good -  everything else was mediocre and there wasn't much of it...  we wound up throwing away half of it as who wants to eat cold potatoes on a mountain of rice?The bottle shop looks adorable, but SG$15 for a pear cider and a bottle of water just seemed insane.  There's free wifi but you have to register with your phone number and a bunch of other info in order to use it so we didn't bother.All in all, we spent SG$42 on what amounted to mostly rice and a little bit of cold food plus a nice cup of tea... I certainly won't come again.  Go to a proper hawker centre for good food at reasonable prices, or go to a proper restaurant for better food and and the same amount of money.

Cool concept - east meet west; teh tarik or G&T; food court by day with live music at night; metal straws at some stalls; stalls decorated as containers or trucks; $1 back when you return your tray, etc. Unfortunately, because of the remote location, it's not yet a destination, so there are periods during the day when the place is kind of dead.

Idiotic hipster hawker centre.The food here is what you'd find at your random, average hawker stall, except at jacked-up prices.The most annoying bit is the $1 deposit to force you to return your tray. I'm sure that(1) Every diner is happy to pay 5¢ for the service of having their trays returned by some auntie.(2) Plenty of seventy-something year-old aunties (who are currently forced to collect cardboard for a living) are happy to be paid 5¢ for each returned tray. (The above is, in effect, what traditionally has always happened at all eating establishments in Singapore, be it at hawker centres, food courts, or your high-class French restaurant. The 5¢ -- or whatever it may be -- cost is simply implicit in the cost of your food order.)Instead, the timbre+ management decided that to save themselves some money, they'd(1) Place the inconvenience and burden of returning trays on each diner. And:(2) Save money by paying the one-time installation cost of the coin-return mechanism thing (maybe at most a few K), instead of paying some auntie $800 a month to do the job.This money-making scheme can then also be couched under the guise of the stupid and misguided progressive "returning your tray" is somehow morally good notion. The hipster fools who love such hipster hawker centres are probably also the same fools who fall sway to such "progressive" notions. KNN timbre+ and these hipsters.

Damian D'Silva is back, and his mini-restaurant within Timbre+ will make his fans (like me) happy. Lucky me that I work upstairs! His classics like nasi lemak are still delicious. $8 for a nasi lemak, you say? But there's a whole fish in there! Sharing Damian's place is the cute little coffee kiosk, Blue Collar Collaborative. Friendly baristas. Dusk by Slake offers some well-priced and delicious meat roasts. Order by the grams. Douglas' fishball noodles are above average.  Not every day you see a 20 something year old Singaporean making his own fish balls. Clams ban mian is comforting especially on a rainy day. Add extra roasted chilli! The bottle shop is well stocked. American modern craft beer heavy with some Japanese (Baird beer, delish) and uk/aussie beers (which I mostly hate). Some ciders.

was at their opening night and the place is the new happening for west-siders.For those who are not aware, this area is the 'Silicon Valley' for startsups.My old incubation agency was located there and wah lao, now I'm gone, such a haps place happened!I was the only one dining while my partner stole my food.Was ravished and went for the no-queue Chit Chaat Chai, had fish bryani and it was MAAADD awesome. Fragnant and well-cooked, definitely a must-order.There's quite a variety of foodstalls here, and in numerous media outlets, they have been featured. i would like to point out that a few hawker stalls from the previous food centre has stayed, but did not checked out the price hike(if any).Some of my friends were worried that the place looked stuffy but well-assured it was well-ventilated.This is an exciting period whereby relevant start-ups could possibly collaborate with Timbre+.* They have an interesting system whereby you get a dollar back when you return your tray.

This is an over glorified hawker centre. It's too bad they didn't do air conditioning. It's really, really hot.Many of the stalls are just okay. There's a good variety but I suspect more effort goes into the decor than the food.Stalls:D's Joint - excellent local heritage food by my favourite chefPortico - paella was a disappointment. Dry and flavourlessGarçons - reasonably priced French food

Meh. Cool place. Nice vibe. But the food truck and restaurant spin-offs are such a rip-off. Especially Garçons. Among others don't order the miso cod with foie gras. Expensive and such a joke in terms of portion (tiny piece) and composition. I asked the Chef where the radish shown in the photo was and he said "oh this is just for illustration purposes. We don't have that radish." Er. Isn't that a problem? I uploaded a photo.

Timbre+ is a cool concept where the place operates as an affordable hawker centre during the day and transforms into a great chill out spot with live music at night. I went for dinner as I heard that it is super crowded and hot during the day. There is no air conditioning but I felt comfortable with just fans at night. It is within walking distance from one north mrt station. The front part is made up of hawker stalls which are mostly closed at night. Once you walk in, you are greeted by colorful food trucks and a vibrant scene. The live music started at 8 plus and was impressive. Food wise I had duck confit from Garçons. The meat was tender and the serving was value for money. One friend had a bak kut Teh set which included drinks and was a good deal. Another friend had sashimi which was only so-so. We also shared fries with salted egg sauce which was addictive. We didn't try alcohol but there seemed to be a decent selection. Another cool thing is how the tray return area has a censor and returns you one dollar for each tray. Overall, I would highly recommend Timbre+ as an enjoyable place to hang out with friends without burning a hole in the wallet.
Food is expensive and doesnt taste fantastic. Place is always crowded with poor ventilation. I dun personally recommend this place to hangout long.
Large apple tea ($4.50) - 3.5 starsAmbience - 5 starsCame here to play a board game with friends in the afternoon when it wasn't too crowded. Perfect!

Marche is always always amazing. The food is fresh and delicious, the ambience cosy and warm. My go-to is the plain rosti (with sour cream and spring onions), chicken schnitzel (fried tender chicken breast with potato salad and cranberry jam) and sometimes a strawberry shortcake or mushroom soup. The crowd is alright on weekdays but be prepared to queue on weekends. I also recommend the pizzas, pastas and wraps. Everything is good here! They use a card payment system, so you'll be given a Marche card upon entry, and you use this card to pay for your food around the restaurant. Prices are reasonable for the quality. A rosti is about 10+ and the schnitzel about 15+. Highly recommended!

I haven't been to Marche in over 10 years, and my friends wanted a place with a variety of food to suit everyone's tastebuds, so we choose Marche. If you don't want to queue a tleast 20 minutes on a thursday night at 7pm, make a reservation.There are lots of tables, some are bar top, and some are booths and some are just typical tables which you can join together to accomodate a big group.1. Watermelon JuiceThe watermelon juice tasted okay, nothing special. I would rather go elsewhere to get this watermelon juice.The rosti station had one of the longest queues!You can pick to have your rosti with sausages, smoked salmon and more.With so many potatoes placed here to decorate the stall, I wonder how much potatoes do they use on a daily basis.2. Rosti with Smoked Salmon $16.90+I loved how generous they were with the smoked salmon, covered the entire plate of rosti! The smoked salmon wasn't too salty, it was perfect and the rosti was crispy on the top layers and soft and warmed to perfection in the center. This was exactly how I remembered it 10 years ago. It seems quality standards remained the same over the past decade! *applause*3. Rosti with SausagesI picked both the chicken cheese sauage and the pork garlic sausage. The chicken cheese sausage was very juicy and flavourful. The pork garlic sausage (the shorter one) was a bit more dry and slightly harder to cut into. The sour cream added more flavour to the sausages.While waiting for my Rosti to be cooked, I watched this chef twirl and spin the pizza dough in the air, it was quite amazing and it made me want to try the pizza.4. Onion Chicken PizzaThe pizza looked fine, till we cut it up and saw the amount of oil in it. The onion was more for decoration as it seemed pretty raw. The chicken cubes were tiny and the cheese wasn't sufficient enough. The outside crust was crispy but the inner pizza was dough and pretty much all the ingredient slid right off the pizza. Very disappointing.5. PastaCheesy goodness and even the brocolli tasted awesome. A decent plate of pasta with simple flavours from the ham and brocolli6. Roasted Half Chicken with SausagesThe chicken was very tender and juicy, even the breast meat was juicy. The sausages here were the same as the ones that came with the smoked salmon.7. SaladThe salad seemed fresh, however there wasn't sufficient dressing on the salad. All in all, there were some hits and misses, and Yes I will go back for more rosti goodness, but I was surprised to see the bill of $140 for 4 pax. Is the food fresh? Yes sort of, I mean I can't say it's super fresh, but I know I didn't get sick from eating it. But the price just doesn't justify the quality of food we received.

Came here on New Year's Eve (2016) and as expected, long lines were formed outside the restaurant.While queuing, one of the staffs asked the crowd (including my friend and I) whether there was a party of two. My friend spotted it pretty quickly and hence we jumped the queue and was given the seat near to the kids' playground (slide).This restaurant do not have much seats available so you might have to wait till other patrons to be done with their food. Compared to the one in Somerset 313, it was narrower. There were plenty of choices (salad bar, crepes, pasta, rosti, dessert, beverages, etc). Upon going into the restaurant, you will be given a card that will be used to swipe the food or beverages you choose from the different sections and pay when you are about to exit the restaurant. The good part about this concept is that the crowds will not walk in and walk out from the same set of doors.I was craving for crepes and hence decided to go for pulled beef with pumpkin sauce. There was a line at that section but I was able to retrieve my order fast. My friend ordered the Smoked Salmon Rosti and it came out much later as there were longer lines formed there.Food wise, I love the crispy crepes and the ingredients were of perfect blend. The beef was chewy and juicy just like I wanted it to be. The portion was more than I expected. For the Smoked Salmon Rosti, it was my first time trying. Love the combinations of the salmon and the rosti. The crisp blended well with the slimy salmon slices. Would probably prefer it to be more smoked salmon slices on this dish.My friend decided to get sweet crepe for dessert. She chose banana chocolate crepe topped with rum ice cream. The banana were generous and the chocolate was not too sweet. This dish was not too sweet as I thought it will be by its look. Overall, this family friendly restaurant has tons to offer. From the indoor decoration to creating a space for the children so that the adults can chit chat. Price wise it is costly but I would not mind to spend a little more once in a while for good food :)

Probably a place that is interesting for children and kids because you can walk around the marketplace, look at the food being prepared etc. Saturday night at Vivo city is a hungry diner's nightmare. We stood in line for about 30 minutes to be seated.The food is OK. Nothing wow but nothing inedible as well.  Mostly all cooked to order, which is nice and also the kids can watch the service staff do their jobs.I got the roasted chicken crepe and the cook behind had the sulkiest face.  Bleh.

Today I tried the pork knuckle half-size with ginger beer. Mâché' price is on the high end and thus this meal is close to $30. Having said that, the pork knuckle tasted fine in that the meat is not too salty and the skin is crispy. The problem is that the skin looked burnt and not very much appetizing. The ambience is good. I came at 6.30pm and there were plenty of seats. It's now 7pm and this place is packed. Suggest to arrive early to pick the best seats.

Located off the HarbourFront MRT station and can be found at the top level, where Sentosa is. If you're craving western style cuisine, mainly european options, this place is for you. Upon entering, you'll be given a card where you take with you to order food from many stations. You will be charged on this card where at the end, you bring to the cashier to be rung up. You pay your food at the end. Stations include an ice cream, crepe, and juice bar. There's a seafood, pasta, and meat station. Plenty of seating and in an cooled area. The AC is not blasted on high, but just enough to keep you comfortable. Everything is made to order, so that's great and you can be assured that your food has not been sitting under a heat lamp. Must go and a great place to get all of your western style cravings.

I go in cycles where I get obsessed with restaurants and this is my latest. I think there was a five day span last month where I ate here six times. The problem of sorts is that there are so many options that I can go twice in one day and have very different meals.The soups are good and seem to be made by hand with fresh ingredients. The fish seems extremely fresh. The rosti enables me to eat what is essentially a cake of french fries and not feel as bad about it because it is so fresh, and the raclette is divine. German sausage also goes well with it. My fiance loves the paella. The savory crepes have a little too much cheese but are good. The salads are wonderful except for the flies that usually surround the lettuce. The only thing I would definitely never have again here is the pasta, which comes in a watery soup-like tomato-flavoured liquid with awkward cubes of vegetable.The sweet crepes with mascarpone taste lighter than they probably are. I didn't like the plum dessert because it tastes like it is just plums cooked in a pie crust full of egg. The lemon meringue pie is so so so good. They are owned by or somehow affiliated with Moevenpick, which means they also have a case full of some of the best ice cream in the world, imported from Switzerland.Although revealing this holds a risk of making the lines even longer at checkout, one of the main draws of this place is that they discount about three items to $10-$13 each day for lunch, with a free drink. So it is kind of like they are encouraging variety.

Ah, Marche, how I remember you from my junior college days. You were such a fad back then, the coolest restaurant concept in town. You've grown up and so have I.Your outlets are all kid-friendly, with ample play area for the little ones to run around in. They are also daddy-friendly, with a selection of beers and desserts.I've moved on from the cheap and good old rosti, and now go for the salads and seafood paella, which comes with enough chicken to share with my toddlers.(I spent $97.70 for 4 adults and 2 toddlers.)

it's been forever since i have been to Marche. it was at my sister's suggestion that we went and we only had desserts in mind. for a weekday lunch hour, it wasn't too crowded. The restaurant is located on the roof top of vivo city and they had tall glass windows all around so the possibility of it becoming a green house was high but they managed to keep the place nice and cool so that's a plus for sure in the hot and humid Singapore. another plus was that we quickly found the dessert station as it was less than 5 meters from the entrance. i was hoping to get ice cream with my waffle but it was a whooping $6 for a scoop on top of the almost $10 waffle with fruits option. i was happy to forgo the extra sugar and focus on  the natural mango that was fresh and juicy! the waffle was nice and crisp since it was made upon order. the lady at the station was super friendly and very generous with the toppings. thanks to her i had a satisfying meal and a pleasant time at the restaurant.the only reason i gave it 3 stars and not more is because of the price. i guess with so many cafes in Singapore serving more outstanding and more delicious waffles, their pricing seemed steep in comparison. if i do go back to Marche, it wouldn't be for their desserts but more likely for their other items on the menu.

lovely place and impressive dining atmosphere, strong recommend the mashed potatoes and juice， main courses was cooked elaborately and staff are friendly, definitely want to come back and try more dishes.

Similar to buffet style; however, you order the items you would like prepared and they cater to your selection. Swedish restaurant (the crêpes are divine) yet the variety is plentiful and everything we had was delicious. No set price: you pay for the items that you select, but it's better than going to the market and cooking yourself.We need to have some in the USA!

We had:1) Pasta Gratin with Pork  & Mushroom - the cheese top crust is a little hard but the taste was nice. Daughter liked it enough. 2) Rosti - nice and crispy! Lovely with a generous spoonful of sour cream! Should have added a cheese sausage to complete the experience!Would return again to fulfill that gap now!

Food is decent and service is ok too. Not the most affordable place for the food you get but is fast and nicely located. I am a usual and will be coming back. Convinence for non Asia food this is a god place.

Marche has been my favourite place for dinner for almost a decade. Back then only the vivo branch existed. Based on my experience, not all the dishes are worth trying. If this is your first time trying this restaurant, here are some of my must-try and must-not-try dishes !Food1. Salad bar- pretty expensive for a small bowl of salad, there are a great variety of vegetables to choose from and most of them are pretty fresh ! Rating- don't bother ordering if you wish to fill your stomach with better food. 3/52. Pasta - marche uses fresh ingredients and their pasta are cooked to near perfection. Rating- worth trying. 4/53. Meat- in my opinion, they serve the best pork knuckle in town. You definitely have to try if you are coming in groups of 4 or more. Avoid ordering the steak as they usually cook in batches which ends up overcooking the steaks. Rating- definite must try for the pork knuckle 5/54. Savoury crepe- unique dish that you cannot really find on other places. However, the portion os pretty big and will be better if shared. Rating- recommended 4.5/55. Rosti- the signature dish of the restaurant. There will always be a long queue during peak hours. However, the potato is cooked to perfection ! They use good quality oil and the portion is just nice for one person. Rating- 4.5/5 6. Pizza/rice- only tried once for each dish. Pizza gives lots of toppings and the serving is huge ! The rice is pretty ordinary. Rating-3.5/57. Seafood - calamari rings are nothing special and do not taste that different from outside. Quite overpriced. Rating- 2.5/5Drinks1. Fruit juice- i do not recommend buying their fruit juice. They will pre-squeeze the drinks in the afternoon and leave it for the rest of the day. Hence they are not really fresh. They charge pretty high for the drinks too. Rating- 2.5/52. Fruit teas - has always been my preferred choice of drink over the years. They serve different selection where you can try before ordering. Rating -4/53. Beer/non-alcoholic drink- they serve a wide selection of non-alcoholic drinks and their beer/wine are also quite unique. Rating-3.5/5Deserts1. Cakes and tarts- they have a wide selection of pastries to choose from and most of them taste really good ! However you will be usually too full to eat more than a slice after meals. Rating- 4/52. Crepes/waffles- my favourite desert is the crepe of the week. No other restaurants have this uniqe dish. However the taste usually varies with the pastry chef. There are days when the crepe taste heavenly and days when it taste like soggy prata. I would recommend getting this crepe in somerset for better quality. Rating- 4/5
I like the self-serving style. Hope I've tried the lunch set on week days. It seemed quite worthy of money.

My friend took me here during my stay in Singapore last year and I was blown away by the format of this restaurant. As other reviewers have pointed out, you are given a card upon entering and you're free to use it as many times as you want at each station. Just don't get carried away with it or else you could be handing over your life savings and you wouldn't even know it. Haha. The food was pretty tasty but to be honest, the one thing that really stood out to me was the seafood paella. I could not stop eating it and really felt like getting seconds. Except there were other food to be devoured. My friend had other dishes and we shared the wealth at our tiny table for two. The only thing that I did not like was that it was rather cramped. I could literally hear the conversation of the table next to us, and holding hot plates of food while avoiding the crowd isn't safe. But I know I'll be coming back here if I ever visit Singapore again. Better yet, Marche, why don't you bring this chain to the States?

You can recognize Marche by the Cow statue outside its store. It was one of the first restaurant to introduce the card system where all spending will be charged in a card handed to the customer and on leaving the place, produce the card to the cashier. The outlet at Vivocity is quite small and it feels especially so during weekends. Queues will form a long way outside the store waiting to be serve. What I usually order is the rosti and the crepes.The interior and exterior has the ambiance and design of a European farmhouse.

Have been coming here since the first Marche opened. What I like about eating out at Marche is the wide variety of food they have. Price wise, I've got to be honest and say it is fairly pricey, and overpriced on certain items even, but in general, the food is above average and you the quantity is good. They use the card system here, so splitting a bill is never an issue, since you're paying for what you eat.

I can't decide if I like this Marche or the one at 313 Somerset the most. I find that both Marches make you 'get lost in time'. You can really take your own sweet time to dine and catch up with friends over food, without worrying you'll be chased out. What's more, it's got a nice and warm environment. Marche at VivoCity is kind of on its own at the third floor; so you have to walk out from the food court side to reach the restaurant. The usual thing I like about Marche is the nice variety of food, and considerably affordable prices. Also, what you see is what you pay, since there is no additional ++. Thumb up for a like!

If Kay Lee runs out of char siew, this is my back up. The queues alone should tell you that Fatty Cheong is a roast meat speciality. The char siew is so good that I'll even have wanton mee, should I be feeling like noodles that day. The wanton mee is really basic, as in it's not good or sub-par, just standard, but once you had the sliced char siew in, it brings the dish to another level. They don't sell out that fast, but lunch queues can get a little crazy.

Pretty good char siew at budget prices. Honestly I wasn't as blown away as I was when I had the char siew at Oversea Restaurant but then again you get what you pay for. Also, they claim to use the same part of the pig i.e. armpit that the store at Tiong Bahru Market does ... slightly better here imo.Personally I prefer my char siew a bit more fatty, but this is quite decent.

Dad and I have a thing. We like fatty pork. And when its roasted? WOAH.Dad took me to eat what was, in his words, "magical char siew which was damn cheap". And boy was it good. You can talk about fat marbling and what choice cut all you want, but to me, the char is everything. How can char siew not have those glorious carbon-y blackened bits!?Its good, tasty pork (yes, the siew yoke's pretty awesome too), and it's not expensive, and it's good and tasty. That is all. Oh it only has four stars because they're not open everyday - think they're shut on Tuesday, which I found out to my detriment, as I showed up one fine Tuesday afternoon.

Char Siwe takes centrestage over at Fatty Cheong, especially a particular cut known as "bu jian tian" which means the part of the pig that hails from the underside of the pig and has not seen the light of day!  Best enjoyed with rice or with wanton noodles, the cuts of charsiew at Fatty Cheong are wonderfully flavoured and have nice marbling and charring. The meats are grilled in-house daily and is easily one of the best roast meat joints here in Singapore. The rest of the roast items on the menu are pretty popular as well, but aren't really earth shattering to shout about. They're above average but that's pretty much it.

address: 460 Alexandra Rd #01-32, Alexandra Retail Centre Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: Tucked away in ARC mall, you can always be sure of a space on a weekend evening. You always worry when there isn't much of a crowd. But in this case I was left wondering why there weren't more people here. Food was decent, Thai street food like Yen Ta Fo and duck noodles. For a $6.90 set including a drink, it's food court prices in a much nicer environment. So little to complain about. There's even a choice of dessert, and my recommendation here is to just stick to the coconut ice cream, don't be tempted by the red ruby.

address: 460 Alexandra Rd #01-32, Alexandra Retail Centre Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: Was looking for coffee at Wang when I chanced upon this new outlet at Alexandra Retail Centre. It must been a while since I was here and am happy to find Pornsak's restaurant here. Just wanted a quick bite and decided to order the Crispy Toast with Taro Dip and a cuppa Thai Iced Tea. The combination of carefully cut and toasted bread squares with the fragrant Taro Kaya was good enough to whip my appetite further. The Taro Dip has a strong pandan taste though. Coupled that with a nice Thai Iced Tea on a hot day today, it makes me wanna linger on for more.  Alas, my missus wouldn't as I am still too close to dinner time.The food selection wasn't that many so I assume this is a quick bite zone. But I am so gonna have my sexy. thai.food. Next time. Will submit another review when I am back for a bite again!

address: 2 Science Park Dr #01-14 Ascent Singapore 118222 Singapore
comment: The outlet shared its seating area with another rice bowl outlet. It offered ramen using French techniques. Duck Confit Maze-men ($16)Shredded duck confit, charred king oyster mushrooms, purple cabbage, carrot, citrus-soy dressing, onsen tamagoLooked quite colorful. Would prefer it to be served with a bowl of soup by the side. Felt a bit jelet after halfway through the dish.Escargot Kara-age (S$9)Spring onion, noisette butter aioli, garlic chips, cherry tomatoInsteresting texture. Lightly crispy outside, while chewy inside, pairing with the wasabi taste aioli.

Bayswater Kitchen is a restaurant on Keppel Bay Island by The Prive Group located right by the side of  the waterfront at the scenic Marina at Keppel Bay. It does have a relaxing and laidback atmosphere inspired by the seaside.The decor and furnishing of Bayswater Kitchen is bright and breezy themed with nautical accents. With the alfresco dining section, the place is rather popular in the evenings as you can enjoy a good view of Keppel Marina.Let alone with good seafood, it would be best to pair with alcohol.In fact the fisherman's feast is recommended by the restaurant as Seafood Lovers "Wet" Dream.Get going and check out what we are having!Their menu is dated with a stamp and that suggested that items on it are subjected to change base on season and what is available in the kitchen.To start, we had the Chargrilled Octopus. It was smoky and grilled to perfect tenderness. The dish was awesome with smoked roe, Gremolata, Borlotti Beans.Chargrilled Octopus - $22The Fisherman's Feast was a scrumptious meal for us. Their homemade hand-rolled linguine was commendable as it was lightly soaked and cooked in their seafood stock. Fisherman feast was not completed without the main ingredients like lobster, prawn, mussel, clams and fish of the season.Fisherman's Feast - $38 per paxThe feast requires a minimum order for 2 pax, that also means you can order similar dish if you are dining in a group and portion will be serve accordingly to per head. Thumbs up to the Fisherman's Feast!All were good from food to environment, perhaps a little shortcoming might be the lights in the restaurant which was quite dim, not an ideal environment for taking pictures. Other than that in terms of service, I would comment that they were very "on-the-ball" be it checking on the taste of the food or topping up our glasses of sparkling water.This place is recommended for a good date and for occasions be it in pairs (couples) or groups. Do remember to make a reservation before heading down.

Made a reservation and was seated immediately. Waiters were very quick with service and very friendly too. Ambience and atmosphere fits the sea and very cooling at night. Started with the Mussels and clams in a pot, really full of food and it seemed almost endless! Tried the lobster mac and cheese, fisherman's pie, fish and chips, fisherman's feast. Seafood stock/broth from the fisherman's feast was rich in flavour and very enjoyable! Fisherman's pie was nice and creamy. Since it was a birthday dinner, they brought out the Bayswater's Bounty Bar which was nice rich chocolate with a good coconut ice cream on top. Even took a polaroid photo and gave a birthday card! Definitely recommended for birthday celebrations :)

comment: These guys are great. This is the kind of stuff I love, when bartenders masterfully create UNIQUE cocktails with local ingredients in a chill ambiance. Frankly, I felt reminded of walking into a friend's house and hanging out in that type of setting. My girlfriend and I walked in at around midnight on a Saturday night and were surprised at how quiet it was. They mentioned that last call would be at 12:30 yet they didn't end up doing so until closer to 2 am so instead of only ordering 1 drink, I got 3 :PMy first was their version of Penicillin with honey, lemon juice, ginger and one of their whiskeys. Except this one they use some chocolate somewhere and do a float of Lagavulin on top and maybe some coconut in there? Took a while to make but that's because of the steps involved, and It is presented in a china type glass that you would drink tea out of along with some homemade tea jelly. This was incredible, definitely taste your usual Penicillin cocktail with a more local twist which is awesome. Easy to drink.The second drink was the bartender's off the menu Old Fashioned drink (since they served the last of one of their ingredients to the Fire Roasted Old Fashioned just beforehand). I don't remember what the bartender did but he did something to make this one sweet but addicting cocktail, definitely one of the best old fashioned twists I've ever had.The last drink was a classic drink that I tried for the first time, called the Boulevardier. I've always loved Negronis and Old Fashioneds, so they made me a drink that has elements of both. I'm hooked.My girlfriend ordered one of their milk drinks with pandan. Although it tasted great, it was just too rich. Difficult to drink more than a few sips.Bartenders are very cool and knowledgable. I love going into places where passion fuels what they do, and you can clearly see these in their drinks.Highly recommend checking this place out at anytime. From the sounds of it, there isn't any queue or wait time for now, so check it out before it starts getting more known and crowded!

comment: Hopscotch Bar markets itself a the go to place for "craft cocktails with a local twist." Boy were they right, I had a Fire Roasted Old Fashioned mixed with gula melaka (palm) and was simply out of this world! The sweetness of the palm sugar coupled with the strong yet smooth bourbon was heavenly. To top it off was a charred dehydrated pineapple slice, which gave the drink a charred/smokey finish. The other drink I tried was the Smokin' Pisang - banana infused bourbon, french fig cordial, sandalwood smoke. As you can tell, I'm a huge bourbon guy. The thought of Mixing banana with bourbon was just too difficult to pass up. I'm glad I didn't. :DThere are so many great cocktail bars in Singapore: Tippling Club, Manhattan, the Library, Cufflink Club and so many others. However, this particular cocktail is very unique in that its cocktails have an Asian Twist. You can't get that in New York. In my opinion, one of the best cocktail bars on the Island!
